au.com.systemic.framework.dao.sql
Class SQLStatement

java.lang.Object
  au.com.systemic.framework.dao.sql.SQLStatement

public class SQLStatement
extends java.lang.Object

Programmer: Joerg Huber

Description & Usage
This class provides some functionality similar to a prepared statement. The advantage is that parameters of an SQL statement can be used with logical names of the form ':varName' instead of a simple '?'. This allows also to bind a value to more than one variable if the variable has the same name.

Example of use
SQL: 'select * from ABC where a=:var1 and n=:var2 and :var1>:var2'
The method bind('var1', 134); will bind both occurances of :var1 in above statement.

Assumption & Constraints
None

Constructor Detail

SQLStatement

public SQLStatement(SQLStatementInfo sqlStatementInfo)
Constructs a SQLStatement object that can be used to execute SQL statements. It requires a SQL statement that conforms the notation as described in the class banner. Further each SQL statement should have an ID that identifies the statement. The statement must contain a ':varName' tags for varaiables that shall be bound later. Example: select * from ABC where ABC.xyz = :someValue In Above example the ':someValue' can be bound before execution with the 'bind' methods of this class.

Parameters:
sqlStatementInfo - The SQL statement information

bindDynamic

public void bindDynamic(java.lang.String varName,
                        java.lang.String value)
Binds a variable to the SQL statement. The 'varName' must be of the form 'varName' without the ':' as in the SQL statement. If there are no variables with the given name then no action is performed.

Parameters:
varName - The Name of the varibale to bind.
value - The value to bind.

bindDynamic

                        java.util.ArrayList dynamicList)

Parameters:
varName - The Name of the varibale to bind.
dynamicList - The ArrayList to bind.

bind

public void bind(java.lang.String varName,
                 java.util.Date value,
                 int dateType)
          throws java.sql.SQLException
This will bind a date to the appropriate variable. The dateType is required to indicate if only the date, time or both components are required. This function assumes that the following formats for date and time are used by the underlying database. Date: String of form: YYYYMMDD Time: String of form: hhmmss (hh = 24 hours) Date & Time: String of form: YYYYMMDDhhmmss (hh = 24 hours)

Parameters:
varName - Name of the variable to bind.
value - Value to bind.
dateType - Part of the date to use.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - If the variable cannot be bound.

bind

public void bind(java.lang.String varName,
                 BaseObject value)
bind a BaseObject directly

Parameters:
varName - String
value - BaseObject

resetBindVariables

public void resetBindVariables()
This method will clear all bind variable values. After this call it is required to call the 'bind' methods again before the 'execute' method can be used.

executeQuery

public java.sql.ResultSet executeQuery(java.sql.Connection conn)
                                throws java.sql.SQLException
This will execute the SQL statement and return the result as a ResultSet. If an error occured SQLException is thrown and an error is logged. If your statement does not return a result set then use execute(Connection).

Parameters:
conn - The connection where to execute the statement.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - Statement failed to execute.

execute

public void execute(java.sql.Connection conn)
             throws java.sql.SQLException
This will execute the SQL statement. If an error occured SQLException is thrown and an error is logged. If your statement does returns a result set then use executeQuery(Connection).

Parameters:
conn - The connection where to execute the statement.
Throws:
java.sql.SQLException - Statement failed to execute.
